question.label: What's this data called?
question.help: People see the name of your open data in a list of similar ones so make this as unambiguous and descriptive as you can in this tiny box so they quickly identify what's unique about it.

question.label: Where is it described?
question.help: Link to the dataset you are certifying. By dataset we mean the documentation or metadata that describes the data as well as a link to the data file itself. Dataset = data + metadata.

if.requirement: You should have a web page that offers documentation about the open data you publish so that people can understand its context, content and utility.
You must have a web page that gives documentation and access to the open data you publish so that people can use it.

question.label: Who publishes this data?
question.help: Give the name of the organisation who publishes this data. It’s probably who you work for unless you’re doing this on behalf of someone else.

question.label: Can individuals be identified from this data?

option.label: no, the data is not about people or their activities
option.help: Remember that individuals can still be identified even if data isn't directly about them. For example, road traffic flow data combined with an individual's commuting patterns could reveal information about that person.

option.label: no, the data has been anonymised by aggregating individuals into groups, so they can't be distinguished from other people in the group
option.help: Statistical disclosure controls can help to make sure that individuals are not identifiable within aggregate data.

option.label: yes, there is a risk that individuals be identified, for example by third parties with access to extra information
option.help: Some data is legitimately about individuals like civil service pay or public expenses for example.

question.label: Is your data listed within a collection?
question.help: Answer yes if this dataset has been registered somewhere else (e.g. as part of a group or collection of related datasets). This helps make your data more discoverable.
question.requirement: You should ensure that people can find your data when they search for it in locations that list data.

question.display: The documentation includes machine-readable data for
question.label: Does your data documentation include machine-readable data for:

option.label: title
option.requirement: You should include a machine-readable data title in your documentation so that people know how to refer to it.

option.label: description
option.requirement: You should include a machine-readable data description in your documentation so that people know what it contains.

option.label: release date
option.requirement: You should include a machine-readable data release date in your documentation so that people know how timely it is.

option.label: modification date
option.requirement: You should include a machine-readable last modification date in your documentation so that people know they have the latest data.

option.label: frequency of releases
option.requirement: You should provide machine-readable metadata about how frequently you release new versions of your data so people know how often you update it.

option.label: identifier
option.requirement: You should include a canonical URL for the data in your machine-readable documentation so that people know how to access it consistently.

option.label: landing page
option.requirement: You should include a canonical URL to the machine-readable documentation itself so that people know how to access to it consistently.

option.label: language
option.requirement: You should include the data language in your machine-readable documentation so that people who search for it will know whether they can understand it.

option.label: publisher
option.requirement: You should indicate the data publisher in your machine-readable documentation so people can decide how much to trust your data.

option.label: spatial/geographical coverage
option.requirement: You should include the geographic coverage in your machine-readable documentation so that people understand where your data applies to.

option.label: temporal coverage
option.requirement: You should include the time period in your machine-readable documentation so that people understand when your data applies to.

option.label: theme(s)
option.requirement: You should include the subject in your machine-readable documentation so that people know roughly what your data is about.

option.label: keyword(s) or tag(s)
option.requirement: You should include machine-readable keywords or tags in your documentation to help people search within the data effectively.

question.help: If you are publishing your data via a data portal platform (e.g. CKAN or Socrata) then metadata will be available via the API, making it machine-readable.

question.label: Has your anonymisation process been independently audited?
question.requirement: You should have your anonymisation process audited independently to ensure it reduces the risk of individuals being reidentified.
